newsitem.title: USA: Warm, dry weather aids Montana planting progress.
newsitem.headline: Warm, dry weather aids Montana planting progress.

text.p: Warm, dry weather allowed a lot of fieldwork to get done in Montana during the week to Sunday, according to the Montana agricultural statistics service in its weekly crop update.
"Small grain seeding is approaching normal levels. There were a few reports of areas in need of rain to start off the spring grains," the report said.
Spring wheat was 62 percent planted, up from 29 percent a week earlier but still behind the five-year average of 73 percent. Twelve percent had emerged, down from a five year average of 28 percent.
Barley was 60 percent planted, up from 28 percent a week earlier but behind the average of 69 percent. Eight percent had emerged, versus a normal 27 percent.
"Central leaf beetle activity was reported in the south central part of the state, which is earlier than normal," the report noted.
Sugarbeets were 94 percent planted, slightly ahead of the average of 87 percent.
Winter wheat ratings declined slightly with 56 percent good or excellent, down from 63 percent a week earlier.
